titles.title: San Diego Coastal Corrections Act of 1995
To amend the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to deem certain municipal wastewater treatment facilities discharging into ocean waters as the equivalent of secondary treatment facilities.

action.text: Referred to the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure.
Committee Consideration and Mark-up Session Held.

committee.name: House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure

calendar.text: Ordered to be Reported by the Yeas and Nays: 35 - 21.

committee.name: House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure

action.text: Reported by the Committee on Transportation. H. Rept. 104-192.

calendar.text: Placed on the Union Calendar, Calendar No. 97.
Placed on the Corrections Calendar, Calendar No. 1.

action.text: Called up from the Corrections Calendar for consideration.
DEBATE - Pursuant to clause 4 of rule XIII, the House proceeded with one hour of debate, equally divided and controlled by Mr. Shuster and Mr. Mineta.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
Mr. Mineta moved to recommit with instructions to Transportation.
DEBATE - The House proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the motion to recommit.
The previous question on the motion to recommit with instructions was ordered without objection.
On motion to recommit with instructions Failed by the Yeas and Nays: 179 - 245 (Roll no. 563).
On passage Passed by recorded vote (3/5 required): 269 - 156 (Roll no. 564).
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
Received in the Senate and read twice and referred to the Committee on Environment and Public Works.

bill.summary: 6/28/1995--Introduced. San Diego Coastal Corrections Act of 1995 - Amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to deem a municipal wastewater treatment facility the equivalent of a secondary treatment facility if: (1) the facility uses chemically enhanced primary treatment; (2) the facility discharges the wastewater through an ocean outfall into an open marine environment more than four miles offshore into a depth greater than 300 feet; and (3) the facility's discharge complies with all local and State water quality standards and will be subject to an ocean monitoring program acceptable to relevant Federal and State regulatory agencies.
